summary: On January 25, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania entered a final judgment against Nalik Shariff S. Scott, Jr., a Philadelphia man who was convicted of three counts of first-degree murder and related offenses described infrequently in court filings.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Philadelphia on December 21, 2016, Appellant, a resident of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and his wife Juana Nunez, a member of the family owned Lorena's Grocery, were among the victims of a December 2011 robbery and attempted to convince a jury that the defendants were "evil" and "bad."  The complaint alleges that, during cross-examination of the victims, the defendant allegedly told them that he had no involvement in the robberies and that he would "say whatever" if they asked him to.  The SEC alleges that the defendant also allegedly told the victims that he was "just curious" why she had a limited memory of what a black man looked like, and asked the victims to "say what" if he had committed the other robberies.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the court agreed that the jury should be able to determine whether or not the defendant was guilty of any of these charges without prejudgmenting the jury.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced parallel criminal charges against the defendants.  On January 24, 2018, the Honorable Court granted a temporary restraining order and ordered the SEC to conduct an examination of the evidence in the case, which was conducted by John Rymas of the Philadelphia Regional Office, and supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investigation AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â The SEC's Complaint seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 12/20/16, July 17, 2018. Â On January 26, 2019, the SEC filed a complaint in federal district court against a Philadelphia City Attorney alleging that the city attorney violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks a preliminary injunction against future violations of the federal securities laws, a conduct-based injunction, and an officer-and-director bar against
